content.description:
This is the single route up the wall just to the right of Standardized Testing and Dunces Corner.  The climb ascends mainly up the center of the wall moving slightly left along the way. 

  See JoeNY's comment below for a more detailed description.
content.protection:
Gear anchor at the top, no bolts. 

  See comment below for lead pro, and setting up a TR and directionals.
content.location: Facing the main Chalkboard wall that hosts Dunces Corner and Pop Quiz, turn 90 degrees to the right and you're facing the wall with Writer's Block.

content.description: The left-most route on this beautiful wall.  Tricky route-finding, almost no gear.  Tall is helpful, but not necessary.  Crux is most definitely moving past the flake.
content.protection: There is very little gear on this route, and what there is, is small.  Best to TR this one (but see comment below).  Bolts to the right for descent, but not useful for TRing this route.
content.location: Start under a large flake approximately 5-8 feet left of the obvious small right-facing corner in the middle of the wall.  Climb up to large flake, follow thin black seam to the top.  Easy walk-off.

content.description: The chimney that is the left end of the Writer's Block face  When blocked by the giant blocks, exit right (crux) onto the steep orange face for a dramatic finish.
content.location: Walk 25 ft right from the Chalkboard area.  The climb starts on a large flat block ledge.  Note - the chimney is mostly too wide for true chimney technique.  But not entirely.

content.description: The middle route on this beautiful wall.  My favorite climb on this wall; very aesthetically pleasing moves, balancy, thin.
content.location: Start underneath the obvious small right-facing corner, pull past small roof (crux), and diagonal up and right (second crux) to finish in dihedral.  Easy walk-off, or bolts on top of Dunce's Corner.

content.description:
Despite its name, this climb doesn't really use the arete.   

  Start at the left of the corner and work your way to the right face and ascend a few feet to the right of the arete.   

  Climb # 87 in the climbing guide (by Wilson/Sauer)
content.protection: Gear anchor at the top - same anchor may be used as Detention
content.location: More or less the same starting point as Detention at the arete on the right side arete of the Writer's Block wall.

content.description: Great hidden chimney past "the chalkboard" walls. This climb is hidden in the cave along the blue/yellow trail (not the terror dome).  Slab for the first 15' then enter and work the chimney up past the small roof on the left to the top.    For trad, there are some options for gear to protect (PG-13).  Nice and cool on a hot day.  Very awkward and alot of fun.
content.protection: No bolts, decent boulders to anchor to at top.  You can sling around the large boulder and enter the top of the chimney to gain access to some crack options to build an anchor.  Also with a long anchor rope there is a flake-like boulder about 20' back towards the upper trail that you can sling for added protection.
content.location: Go past the chalkboard and instead of following the trail stay close to the wall through a cave-like path. Fun. Pretty obvious chimney. The left face is covered in lichen.

content.description: A few pumpy ledges to a thin crack system.
content.location: Climb the face to the left of School Chimney.

content.description: Git thy bad self in that there dihedral, and squirm!  Kind of a one- or two-move wonder, but fun nonetheless.  Very obvious crux.  The easiest of the three on this wall.
content.protection: Protection is good.  Double-bolted anchor at the top of this route.
content.location: Follow the right-facing dihedral to the top.

content.description:
On the right edge of the Writer's Block wall is an arete.  Follow the left side of the arete up to the top. 

  Climb # 86 in the climbing guide (by Wilson/Sauer)
content.protection: Gear anchor at the top.  No bolts.
content.location: Along the arete on the right edge of the Writer's Block wall

content.description: The next chimney to the right of Honey Badger.  It's the second one you hop over as you walk out to the bolts atop Skink.  Not as squeezy as Honey Badger, so it should appeal to more folks.
content.protection: A pair of #3 Camalot size cams will suffice if you want to build a TR anchor (a horizontal takes gear too if you want a third piece).  Gear in the chimney is nothing out of the ordinary.  You could place a #4 BigBro if you had one but it's not necessary.  The friction in there is excellent and the chimney moves are very secure.
content.location: While the chimney extends to ground level (the route is named for the really neat cave at the base at the base of the cliff here; check it out), you really need to start on the big ledge 20 ft off the ground.  Scramble up a bit in the cleft just left of the large black birch tree, then walk right on the large ledge behind the tree.  You can't miss the chimney.

content.protection: Mainly Top-roping - There is only one tree at the top that is not a Pitch Pine.  (Pitch Pines are protected and the rangers will ask you to remove any anchors from them, but there's a bomber giant one here that is oh so tempting...)
content.location: The start is about 15 feet right around the corner from Milil's Magic Arete.  It follows the corner crack all the way.

content.description: Very different type of climbing - tiny quartz crystals and small horizontals, with few big jugs and an actual fingercrack in a dihedral.  Some of the more technical climbing in PK; routes from 5.8 to 5.12.  Home to one of the few double-bolted anchors.
